section.title: Nagios
section.para: This section describes the Qlustar Nagios setup.

section.title: Nagios Plugins
section.para: The package ql-nagios-plugins contains the tools required to process the data received from ganglia. The thresholds, services and nodes to monitor and group definitions are set in files located in the directory /etc/nagios3/conf.d/ql. The file nodes.cfg lists the nodes. A few lines are required for each node:
The file hostgroup-definitions.cfg defines which nodes belong to which hostgroup:

The regular expression beo-0. specifies that all nodes whose hostname match the expression belong to this group. If you need to create another group because not all metrics are available for all nodes, or some metrics require different thresholds than you can do so here:

The file service-definitions.cfg lists all metrics that should be monitored. It includes the threholds, and for which groups each service is defined. It should be a passive check, and ql-hwmonitord should be configured to send the data. The following example defines a service only for the members of the group opterons:
section.screen: define service { use generic-service hostgroup_name opterons service_description Ganglia fan1 check_command return-ok passive_checks_enabled 1 active_checks_enabled 0 register 1 }
section.para: The check_command will be ignored, only the information from ql-hwmonitord will be used. The following example defines the service for the members of both groups:
section.screen: define service { use generic-service hostgroup_name ganglia-nodes,opterons service_description Ganglia fan1 check_command return-ok passive_checks_enabled 1 active_checks_enabled 0 register 1 }

Note that you can use quotes to group a field that contains spaces. You can modify the start options that are used at boot time in /etc/default/ql-hwmonitord. For example to increase the interval the metrics are checked to 300 seconds:

Torque Healthcheck An additional value provided by Ganglia on the nodes is the Health check of Torque Mom (see section 6.5.1). If this parameter is in an error state the node can be set offline to prevent any jobs from running on this node. The following section in the file service-definitions.cfg defines this service for all nodes in the group ganglia-nodes:
section.screen: define service { use generic-service hostgroup_name ganglia-nodes service_description Torque Health check check_command return-ok passive_checks_enabled 1 active_checks_enabled 0 event_handler offline-pbsnode!$HOSTNAME$ register 1 }
section.para: The event handler offline-pbsnode will set the node offline if the state changes from OK to CRITICAL and back online if the state changes from CRITICAL to OK. This event handler is defined in /etc/nagios-plugins/config/ql/event-handlers.cfg:

section.title: head node
section.para: The file localhost.cfg lists the services that should be monitored for the head node. The definitions are different because the data is not collected through ganglia.

listitem.para: The RAID devices are monitored by mdadm and mail is sent to root if a device fails. The RAID devices are not monitored with the nagios setup by default.

section.title: Webinterface
section.para: You can open the Webinterface at the address . Login as nagiosadmin. You can change the password by executing the command htpasswd /etc/nagios3/htpasswd.users nagiosadmin as root.

section.title: Restart
section.para: Nagios uses the information collected by Ganglia. When this information source is not available then nagios will send warning mails. To avoid the sending of these mails when you need to restart ganglia you should first stop nagios:
